metadata.title: Dementia  Occupational Therapy
synonyms: dementia due to traumatic brain injury (tbi)
dementia due to other general medical conditions
description: The term dementia refers to conditions in which a person gradually develops multiple cognitive deficits, including memory impairment, as a result of physiological changes caused by a general medical condition, persisting effects of a substance, or a combination of these factors.(1,2) Dementia does not refer to low intellectual functioning or intellectual disability (ID) as these are considered static conditions, whereas dementia represents a decline from previous functioning.(23) Dementia is not a normal condition of aging but rather a symptom of a disease process(3)

According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders,  fifth edition (DSM -5),dementia falls into the category of neurocognitive disorder (NCD), which is a group of disorders whose primary clinical deficit is decreased cognitive function and that are acquired rather than developmental. Dementia is now included in the entity “major NCD.” The term dementia can still be used in identifying subtypes, and may be used in settings in which physicians and patients are accustomed to using the term; however, NCD is the term now being advocated for use in identifying etiology (e.g., NCD due to Alzheimer disease, vascular NCD, NCD with Lewy bodies, NCD due to Parkinson disease, frontotemporal NCD, NCD due to TBI).The term major NCD is also preferable for cognitive impairment caused by conditions affecting younger persons such as TBI or HIV infection(1)
Among persons with dementia 50–60%  have dementia of the Alzheimer type, whereas 15–30%  have vascular dementia(23)
Some form of dementia is reported in about 1%–2%  of patients at age 65 and 30% at age 85(50)
The DSM -5 also recognizes a less severe level of cognitive impairment, mild NCD, which was included in DSM -IV under Cognitive Disorders Not Otherwise Specified(1)

Diagnosis of both major NCD and mild NCD requires evidence of significant cognitive decline from previous levels of performance in one or more cognitive domains—i.e., complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor function, or social cognition—based on both of the following:(1) –Concern of the individual or a family member (a knowledgeable informant) or the clinician that there has been a significant decline  –An impairment in cognitive performance documented by standardized neuropsychological testing (or another quantified clinical assessment)

In addition, for the diagnosis to be made, the cognitive deficits must interfere with independence in everyday activities, the cognitive deficits must not occur exclusively in the context of delirium, and the cognitive deficits cannot be better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder, schizophrenia)(1)
For purposes of this Clinical Review, the term dementia will be used

Patients with dementia will have significant difficulty learning new information and may forget previously learned information and skills.(1) Initially, the memory impairment results in losing things or getting lost in unfamiliar settings; however, as the dementia progresses, the patient may start to forget his or her occupation, family members, birth date, and name(1)
Although uncommon, dementia can occur in children and adolescents as a result of a general medical condition(1)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. It is unethical and, in most cases, illegal to provide direct treatment to patients when positive treatment outcomes cannot be anticipated, as in the case of some patients with severe dementia. Insurance payors require that any plan of care for a patient with dementia is reasonable and medically necessary for therapy to be reimbursed
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients with dementia will present with memory impairment (often as the initial symptom) and at least one of the following cognitive disturbances:(1)

Aphasia(1) –Word-finding  problems –Empty speech with circumlocutory phrases or frequent use of indefinite words such as “it” or “stuff” –Echolalia (repetition of what is heard) or palilalia (repeating the same word or sound over and over) –Impaired auditory and reading comprehension –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with aphasia, see the series of Clinical Reviews  on this topic

Apraxia(1) –Patients with dementia can present with difficulty executing known motor acts (such as waving goodbye) or an inability to gesture/pantomime use of objects –For detailed information on assessment and treatment of patients with apraxia, see the series of Clinical Reviews  on this topic

Agnosia(1) –Agnosia is an inability to recognize or identify objects, persons, or sounds despite intact sensory function –For additional information on assessment and treatment of patients with agnosia, see  Clinical Review…Agnosia  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708855

Impairment of executive functioning(1) –Executive functioning involves both the capacity to think abstractly and the ability to plan, initiate, sequence, monitor, and stop complex behaviors –Patients with impairment of executive functioning can have difficulty managing novel tasks and often avoid situations in which they would be required to process new or complex information

Frequently occurring coexisting conditions –Agitation or combative behaviors(2) -The best approach to manage these behaviors is a person-centered  care approach using dementia-focused communication skills –Motor disturbances, impairment of gait, and subsequent falls(1) -For additional information on older adults and falls, see  Clinical Review…Falls in Older Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708541 –Disinhibited behavior such as inappropriate jokes, poor personal hygiene, inappropriate familiarity with strangers, and lack of appropriate social conduct(1) –Dysarthria/slurred speech(1) –Mood disorders (anxiety, depression) and psychosocial symptoms(1,2) –Catastrophic reactions and severe emotional outbursts(3) –Delusions or visual hallucinations(1) –In children and adolescents with dementia, delays in or deviation from normal development and/or deterioration in school performance can occur(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with dementia often have poor insight and lack awareness of their own cognitive deficits. They are often very frustrated and frequently deny that they have a problem. It is very important to consider a patient’s level of frustration and level of awareness during assessment and treatment so as not to offend or upset the patient(1)

overall contraindications precautions: It is highly recommended that family members be involved in the assessment and treatment process as much as possible. Cultural background, language preference, and patient interests must also be considered(1)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients with dementia often have poor insight and lack awareness of their own cognitive deficits. They are often very frustrated and frequently deny that they have a problem. It is very important to consider a patient’s level of frustration and level of awareness during assessment and treatment so as not to offend or upset the patient(1)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review medical history, including date of initial diagnosis, presenting symptoms, psychological and/or neuropsychological tests and reports, drug regimen, and medical, behavioral, and social management of dementia to date -Document the underlying cause of dementia and inquire about the general progression of symptoms

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management varies according to the etiology of dementia(1) Treating the underlying pathology may reverse dementia symptoms in some conditions (e.g., vitamin deficiency, infections, endocrine conditions) When the dementia cannot be reversed, medical management may include support and counseling, medications to improve mood and/or behavior symptoms, environmental modification, and lifestyle changes Recommendations for assessment and care of individuals with dementia developed by an interdisciplinary Dementia Measures Work Group (DWG) representing major national organizations and advocacy groups include the following(13) Staging of dementia Cognitive assessment Functional status assessment  Neuropsychiatric symptom assessment Management of neuropsychiatric symptoms Screening for depressive symptoms Counseling regarding safety concerns Counseling regarding risks of driving Palliative care counseling and advanced care planning Caregiver education and support
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? The first treatment to target the fundamental pathophysiology of Alzheimer disease (or any kind of dementia) was granted accelerated U.S. FDA approval in adults in June 2021. Patients receiving aducanumab in trials had a significant reduction of amyloid beta plaque compared to controls, who had no reduction of amyloid beta plaque. More research is needed to prove its effectiveness, but early evidence is promising(53) Medications commonly prescribed to improve functioning in patients with dementia can have significant side effects, including nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, insomnia, and anorexia(2) Contact a pharmacist or physician regarding questions about side effects(2)(2) Donepezil Galantamine Rivastigmine Memantine(2) Cholinesterase inhibitors for apathy, delusions, and purposeless motor behaviors SSRIs for depression Antipsychotics Anticonvulsants
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Diagnostic tests completed for patients with dementia usually include:
Blood work (CBC, platelets, PT[INR], PTT, BUN, creatinine, glucose, thyroid function, liver function, vitamin B12 level)(2)
Often reveal cerebral atrophy, focal brain lesions (from cortical strokes, tumors, hematomas), hydrocephalus, or periventricular ischemic brain injury(1)
Functional imaging tests (PET or SPECT scan)(1)
Not routinely used, but can provide information for differential diagnosis in patients whose neuroimaging tests are negative(1,2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had psychotherapy, occupational therapy, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Are there certain situations or environmental triggers that cause the patient to have more difficulty or that exacerbate symptoms? -Environmental triggers such as poor lighting or noisy, busy environments can trigger agitation or aggression in patients with dementia(2) -It is important to determine the types of sensory stimuli, including tastes, smells, sights, sounds, and touches, that can trigger agitation or other maladaptive behavior so that these may be avoided during therapy sessions(27) -Are there activities that seem to alleviate or lessen symptoms?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS), 010  scale, or a nonverbal scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much )
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Sleep disturbances are common in patients with dementia(1) -Does the patient experience increased symptoms at the end of the day? -The term sundowning is used to describe a pattern of symptoms at the end of the day and into the night in persons with dementia that can include increased confusion, anxiety, agitation, and not being able to fall asleep and stay asleep -Document number of awakenings/night, if occurring -Document sleep aids and frequency of use -Document amount of sleep the patient gets each night -Adequate rest is recommended to reduce cognitive symptoms(2) -Does the patient sleep during the day? If so, how many hours and when? -Sleep patterns may be interrupted, with night/day cycles reversed(14)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., swallowing difficulty, dizziness, headache, bowel/ bladder/sexual dysfunction)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient become short of breath? If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise? Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -Typically, learning and recall are impaired. Declarative memory for facts is impaired and difficult to rehabilitate, whereas procedural memory for how to perform overlearned tasks is retained and responsive to training(15)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of a communication disorder, cognitive impairment, or mental illness? History of head injury or stroke?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, complications of pregnancy, other psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Increased confusion and decreased cognition can result from physical or physiological changes caused by acute conditions or their treatment(14) For example, individuals with dementia who sustain a hip fracture may have a significant decline in cognitive function immediately postoperatively
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What are the patient’s occupation and role(s) within his or her family? -What activities, hobbies, etc., does the patient enjoy?  -A patient/caregiver interview may be helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community role(s), interests, prior work status, and home responsibilities(1) -Seek out specific examples of the impact the patient’s memory and cognitive impairment has had on occupational and social functioning (e.g., leaving the stove on unintentionally, getting lost, forgetting appointments)(1) -An iPad application, Aid for Decision-making  in Occupation Choice (ADOC), was found to provide individualized information regarding meaningful activities for patients with moderate dementia.(20)The app is designed to help promote shared decision making. It utilizes images of ADLs that the patient can select -A Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) score of 8 or above is required for use to retain the application’s sensitivity and specificity
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be used based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Does the patient live at home or in a facility? With cognitive decline, the progression from requiring no assistance to requiring full assistance may take years.(14) If living at home, document stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, close friends or neighbors Support for the caregiver is often just as important as support for the patient with dementia(48) -Caregivers are in a physically and emotionally demanding role -The needs of patients with dementia are continually changing and therefore caregivers must constantly be adapting and changing their roles -Caregivers often have lost their emotional connection with the patient. It is important that they continue to have and develop connections with others to maintain these types of connections that may have been lost for their own health and well-being Determine the impact of memory impairment on the patient’s living arrangement. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any home modifications necessary?(1)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive technology and adaptive devices; incorrect use of devices can increase risk of falls(3) –Assistive/adaptive technology and devices (e.g., stove plate guard, electronic medication reminder, one-button  cell phone) not only increase independence for patients with dementia, but can also substantially improve safety and reduce injury risk(3) -Patients with dementia will not use devices they do not like or understand; it is important to involve the patient and caregiver as much as possible in the selection of appropriate assistive devices to promote patient follow-through  with device usage(26) -Cost of devices and equipment can be prohibitive for some families because some assistive devices and equipment are not reimbursable by third-party  payers -For some types of technology (e.g., passive positioning alarms), patients with mild dementia may see value (e.g., improve freedom and independence) in the device for themselves and their caregivers, but feel that having exposure to and experience with the device prior to significant decline would allow them to participate more in the decisions pertaining to use of the device(34) –There are both enablers of and barriers to use of assistive technology(33) -Enablers -increasing awareness of available technology and decreasing stigma associated with its use -increased affordability and accessibility of assistive technology -including persons with dementia in the assessment of their assistive technology needs -Barriers -need for accounting for disease progression in recommendations for assistive technology -need for continued innovation –Mobility aids -Cane -Walker -Wheelchair -Crutches -Hemi-walker -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) -Patient lifters and transfer aids –Toileting and showering equipment -Grab bars -Bedside commode -Urinal at bedside -Raised toilet seat -Shower chair/tub bench -Elevated footrest at the toilet –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers  -Personal digital assistant (PDA) -Large-print  reading material -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Text-to-speech  software -Adaptive cooking equipment –For detailed information on assistive technology for patients with cognitive impairments, please see  Clinical Review…Occupational ; CINAHL Topic ID Number
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADL tasks involving weight shifting –Tinetti Balance Scale –Berg Balance Scale –Functional Reach Test
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesComplete ergonomics assessment as appropriate; assess body mechanics of caregiver if patient requires assistance with mobilityBed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activitya measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility18-item,  7-level ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking –If the patient presents with impaired gait or decreased safety while ambulating, referral to physical therapy may be appropriateAssess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities; describe the quality of movement –Patients with dementia can have apraxia, which can contribute to difficulty performing motor tasks and ADLs(1) -Assess for apraxia by asking the patient to demonstrate specific motor acts such as copying drawings, brushing his or her hair, or creating a design from blocks or sticks(1) –Assess tone and coordination or dexterity of the upper extremities as these may be affected by the underlying cause of the dementia
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT with muscles with contracture or in the presence of abnormal tone or coordination –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess grip force in functional tasks –Assess pinch strength using a pinchmeter
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess visuospatial processing by having the patient copy drawings (e.g., circles, overlapping squares, stars)(1)
Perform ocular motor screening; includes tracking through all planes, visual accommodation, and clarity of vision
Document complaints of double vision, optic pain, or visual field cuts
Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  is appropriate if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Patients with dementia often have poor insight, resulting in lack of an awareness of their own cognitive deficits(1) –Cognitive assessment for patients with dementia should include a formal measure of memory(1) -Asking the patient to register, retain, recall, and recognize novel information (such as a group of words, numbers, or pictures)(1) -Registration – repeat the new information immediately -Retention/recall – repeat the new information after a delay of several minutes -Recognition – identify the new information given a list that includes both the previously learned information and some information the patient has never seen before -Patients with dementia who have difficulty learning and recalling new information will not be assisted by prompts, cues, and multiple choices because they did not learn the information in the first place(1) -Patients whose memory impairment is specifically related to retrieval of older information will benefit from cues or choices -Assess remote memory by asking the patient to recall historical information (either personal or general knowledge)(1) –Assess executive functioning; impairments of executive functioning are common in patients with dementia(1) -Executive functioning involves both the capacity to think abstractly and the ability to plan, initiate, sequence, monitor, and stop complex behaviors -Assess abstract thinking by asking the patient to explain idioms or find the similarities and differences between two items -Patients with impaired executive functioning can have difficulty shifting between tasks; assess both verbal and nonverbal task shifting -Other assessments of executive functioning include counting to 10, reciting the alphabet, subtracting serials 7s, naming as many animals as possible in 1 minute, and writing a continuous line of alternating m’s and n’s (51,52,53) -The most widely used cognitive screening test in primary care -It evaluates verbal memory recall (immediate and delayed), attention,orientation, working memory, language, and visual spatial functions -Scores range from 0 to 30 -Scores of 23-34  or 24-25  arepositive for dementia in most primary care populations -Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) -Shortened or modified versions of the MMSE –For patients with aphasia, review reports from speech-language  pathology for information about type and extent of language deterioration(1) –Obtain and review testing done by neuropsychology

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Patients with dementia are at risk for wandering
Restraint issues should be addressed if needed; follow facility guidelines and state regulations

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The occupational therapist (OT) will determine the need for intervention after a comprehensive evaluation; the OT must consider each patient’s risk factors and deficits to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for therapy. Therapy for patients with dementia is caregiver intensive.A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for maximizing successful outcomes for each patient with dementia.(26) According to the American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA) practice framework, the domain of occupational therapy practice encompasses an individual’s performance of everyday activities, sorted into “areas of occupation.” Occupational areas most affected by dementia are ADLs, IADLs, rest and sleep, leisure, and social participation.(14)Overall, research on the effectiveness of occupational therapy interventions as well as the barriers to intervention is lacking(35)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out or diagnose diseases and/or psychological disorders prior to making a diagnosis of dementia. The differential diagnosis for dementia includes:(1) Delirium Amnestic disorder ID Schizophrenia Major depressive disorder Malingering or factitious disorders
prognosis: The degree of reversibility and the prognosis for the patient with dementia will depend on the underlying etiology(1)
A patient with severe/advanced dementia has a poorer prognosis due to the increased risk of accidents and infectious diseases associated with severe/advanced dementia(1)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to physical therapy if the patient has difficulty with gait, ambulation, balance, transfers, or weight-bearing Referral to speech therapy for swallowing impairment or communication issues Referral to ophthalmology and audiology as mentioned above Referral to recreational or vocational therapist for returning to activities of leisure Referral to hospice or palliative care for end-of-life  care and support when appropriate Referral to psychiatry, psychology, or social work if patient has signs of depression or anxiety and/or may benefit from assistance with issues such as facility placement
other considerations: Set feasible, individualized goals for occupational therapy treatment for patients with dementia and their caregivers to increase the likelihood of success and compliance(26)

Having a family member with dementia can be extremely stressful for the patient’s loved ones, caregiver(s), spouse, and family(3) –Consider the entire family/support network during evaluation and treatment of the patient with dementia; refer for caregiver training and/or counseling where appropriate(3) –Researchers who conducted an RCT of 46 caregivers of patients with dementia in Taiwan found that psychosocial intervention (problem-solving  skills, knowledge of dementia, social resources, and emotional support) reduced caregiver burden by helping caregivers adopt more problem-focused  and social-support-oriented  coping strategies(25) –The well-being  and behavioral stability of patients with dementia are heavily influenced by the well-being  of their caregivers.(13) Caregivers are sometimes referred to as “secondary patients”

Authors of a systematic review assessing the cost-effectiveness  of prevention, care, and treatment strategies for dementia found tailored activity programs and occupational therapy to be more cost-effective  than usual care(19)

Developing communication partner training (CPT) programs for healthcarestaff working with patients with dementia and other types of neurologically based disorders is important in improving communication and overall care. Currently there are CPT programs for stroke, TBI, and dementia. Authors of a study examining different CPT programs recommended finding the similarities between them todevelop a more efficient CPT program that can address a range of neurogenic communication disorders, which in turn could help improve outcomes for these types of patients(49)
treatment summary: Therapy might focus on improving medication/time management, ADLs/IADLs, community mobility, establishing daily routines, social integration, patient and caregiver education, and functional behavior training –Occupational therapy programs for patients with dementia should be tailored to the needs, goals, prior level of function, coping strategies, and motivational factors of eachpatient(26) –When working with patients with dementia: -Use simple, one-step  directions(3,8) -Avoid conducting therapy sessions in places that are overly crowded or unfamiliar to the patient, as this may lead to agitation and/or frustration(3) -Provide activities that stimulate memory (e.g., music or activity the patient used to enjoy)(3) -Create routines/schedules for the patient and caregiver and use timers and clocks as reminders and to orient the patient(8) -Avoid expressions and idioms that may be taken literally -Whenever possible and appropriate, go along with the patient rather than argue, explain, or correct(8) -Attempt to redirect or distract the patient if he or she is becoming distressed or agitated(8) -Use positive language and encouraging statements frequently when working with a patient with dementia(8) -Break down large tasks into smaller, more manageable parts(8) -Allow extra time for tasks and activities; do not rush the patient(8) -Have the patient wear a medical identification bracelet that indicates that the patient is memory-impaired(3)

Researchers who conducted a meta-analysis  of nonpharmacological interventions by family caregivers to manage behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia concluded that interventions that are multicomponent, tailored to the needs of the caregiver and person with dementia, and delivered at home with periodic follow-up should be implemented(26) –Authors of a further review of the abovementioned meta-analysis  pointed out that the studies with the most significant positive effects utilized interventions delivered or developed by OTs: caregiver education, skills training, and engagement in meaningful occupations(27)

Authors of a retrospective study (N = 30) evaluated a multicomponent rehabilitation program for community-dwelling patients with dementia and their caregivers(47) –The multicomponent rehabilitation program lasted for one year and consisted of 25 counseling sessions and two home visits. The sessions were led by various members of the multidisciplinary team, including a geriatrician, a neurologist, an OT, a social worker, and a psychologist. The program consisted of three main phases: -Assessment and goal setting -Educating caregivers in cognitive and behavioral interventions to support patient  -Counseling sessions on adaptations to living environment and assistive devices as needed –Patients with dementia showed no changes in everyday functioning and cognition, but in more than 60% of patients QOL improved and mood and emotional and behavioral disturbances stabilized. In 64% of the caregivers, the mild to moderate burden of care remained stable or improved

Authors of an RCT conducted in India suggest that a novel occupational therapy intervention improved QOL in older adults with mild to moderate dementia in a hospital setting(24) –Seventy-seven  subjects (80.5% male) were randomly assigned to novel occupational therapy intervention group or control group. Both groups received standard medical treatment –Novel occupational therapy intervention was 10 70-minute treatments over 5weeks, consisting of relaxation, physical exercises, personal care and household activities, cognitive exercises (including dual-task  activity), and recreational activity under the guidance of a trained OT. It was considered a “novel” intervention because it targeted 5 domains: physical, functional, behavioral, psychological, and cognitive rather than fewer domain, as traditional interventions do –The study utilized WHO’s quality of life (WHOQOL) assessment. Because dementia-specific  QOL scales were not available in Hindi, the study listed this as a limitation –Specific gains for the intervention group were improved physical well-being  (physical performance, improved sleep quality, increased energy) and psychological well-being (greater appreciation for life, reduction in negative feelings such as anxiety and depression) –The authors suggested that application to clinical practice will require larger studies assessing the intervention over longer periods of time and in the community setting

Authors of a review of literature from the United Kingdom examining occupational therapy interventions for caregivers of individuals with dementia found a lack of strong evidencefor the interventions currently provided by OTs(9) –It was difficult to compare interventions due to the wide range of outcome measures used in studies –The studies included in the review did consistently find high levels of caregiver burden, depression, stress, distress, and reduced overall well-being –The one intervention that appeared to be beneficial for caregivers was reminiscence therapy (in which the patient with dementia is guided through discussions of past events, experiences, or activities using pictures or other memorabilia)

Researchers who conducted a randomized controlled study in Hong Kong found productive activities with reminiscence in occupational therapy to also be beneficial to patients with dementia(22) –Thirty patients with dementia were randomly assigned to either intervention or control group –Intervention group met for six 40-minute  sessions in which they made and ate rice balls while reminiscing about events in the past. Control group only ate rice balls –Cornell Scale for Depression in Dementia (CSDD) and MMSE showed decreased depression in intervention group when compared to control. There was also significant improvement in task performance in the intervention group as measured by photographs of the finished product (rice balls)

Community occupational therapy in dementia (COTID) program –The COTID programconsists of10sessions of home-based occupational therapy(45) -Sessions 1–4include  an occupational performance history interview for the patient andan ethnographic interview with the primary caregiver, andmay include the COPM for both patient and caregiver. These sessions are directed towards goal setting (targeted towards the patient and his or her motivation), strategies to improve function in ADLs, and prioritizing activities meaningful to them -Sessions 5–10  consist of home-based  occupational therapy focused on: -efficient compensatory strategies -environmental and social modifications -training and education for caregivers -problem solving –Authors of a study (N = 27) evaluated a COTID program for patients with dementia and their caregivers in Italy(45) -The 10 sessions were delivered over 5weeks -The COPM and the Sense of Competence Questionnaire (SCQ) to assess caregiver burden were administered before and after the program to assess outcomes -There was significant improvement in COPM scores of the patients and SCQ scores of the caregivers -No significant improvements were found in overall cognitive function, behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, daily functioning, depressive symptoms, perceived QOL, or global health in the patients with dementia  -The COTID program was found to befeasible in Italy and positive results show that it may be beneficial to both patients with dementia and their caregivers –Authors of an RCT (N = 460 patients and their caregivers) evaluated the COTID program in the United Kingdom compared to treatment as usual in patients with dementia and their caregivers(46) -COTID program group: received 10in-home  sessions over the course of 10 weeks -Treatment as usual (control group): received the usual local service provided, which may or may not include occupational therapy -There was no statistical difference found between the two groups. The COTID program for patients with dementia did not increase their ADL function, their mood, their QOL, or their caregiver’s sense of competence or mood compared to the usual care provided -Patients and their caregivers completing the COTID program set an average of 4.09 goals each. Ninety-one  percent of goals were fully or partially achieved by the end of the 10 sessions. This could not be compared to the control group, because they did not set goals as part of their program

Tailored Activity Program (TAP) –The TAP consists ofeight home-based  occupational therapy sessionsover a period of 3–4 months.(4,39)It has been implemented and studied in the United States and several other countries, including being successfully translated into Portuguese and adapted to the Brazilian culture(39) -Phase I: OT uses a set of assessments to evaluate caregiver communication/management techniques, identify the patient’s strengths, and assess the home environment -Phase II: OT educates caregiver about the role of environment and activities in dementia care and instructs the caregiver on specific techniques and activities -Phase III: OT continues to provide caregiver training and support and helps the family, if applicable, generalize specific strategies to challenges in caring for the patient -Sessions most often involve both the patient and the caregiver -Activities are tailored to the patient’s specific needs and preferences -Examples of activities -Sorting family photos into an album -Singing songs with grandchildren -Snapping green beans for dinner -Wiping down silverware -Balloon toss -Matching card game -Taking a walk -Watching birds at the bird feeder -Arranging flowers in a vase -Authors of a study who assessed caregiver-patient dyads during the TAP found the following:(4) -95% of patients wanted to participate in sessions -96% of caregivers indicated that the sessions were somewhat useful or very useful -100% of patients participated in activities with a rating of engagement of somewhat or very much -86% of caregivers reported somewhat or very much lower angry and challenging patient behavior –Authors of a study (N = 21) evaluated the efficacy of the TAP outpatient version (TAP-O)  to reduce neuropsychiatric symptoms and caregiver burden in patients with dementia compared to a control group(40) -TAP-O  group: Eight sessions over a 3-month  period (one session per week). TAP-O  was adapted from the in-home version of TAP,but few modifications were needed. It consisted of the same three phases of the TAP program and the sessions were conducted at an outpatient memory clinic -Control group: Patients received regular care and participated in psychoeducation group sessions lead by an OT over eight sessions in the outpatient clinic -Compared to the control group, the TAP-O  group had a significant decrease in hallucinations, agitation, anxiety, aggression, sleep disorders, aberrant motor behavior, and caregiver burden -In this preliminary study, the TAP-O  intervention was successful in decreasing neuropsychiatric symptoms and caregiver burden in patients with dementia

ADLs/IADLs –Developing plans and routines to successfully complete ADLs/IADLs is important for patients with dementia(3) –Focus on ADLs/IADLs that the patient enjoys and finds meaningful; training those ADLs/IADLs that stimulate the patient’s memory (e.g., cooking his or her favorite recipe, listening to or playing a favorite song) can be particularly helpful for a patient with dementia(3) –Allow increased time for patients to complete ADLs/IADLs; provide patient and caregiver education regarding extended time to complete self-care  routines where appropriate –Researchers who conducted an evidence-based  review of both pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic interventions for functional and cognitive limitations in patients with mild to moderate dementia found that there was some indication that therapy focused on ADLs improves functional performance in this patient population(10) –If needed, the OT can help the patient select assistive devices and then train the patient to use them to increase independence in ADLs/IADLs -Role-play  with the patient and family to demonstrate use of devices and equipment in ADLs/IADLs(3)

Cognitive stimulation therapy (CST) –CST is a therapy for patients with mild to moderate dementia that includes activities that the patient finds meaningful and enjoyable that also provide cognitive training for memory, attention, or problem solving(11) -Canadian researchers who conducted a systematic review of the literature examining CST for individuals with dementia found that although the cognitive changes following CST for individuals with mild to moderate dementia were small, the fact that there was an overall trend towards improvement or maintenance of cognitive functions was an indication that CST is both meaningful and functionally significant(11) -The results of an RCT of aCST program were compared with the published data from trials of major dementia drugs; researchers concluded that “cognitive stimulation did as well as galantamine or tacrine and substantially better than rivastigmine or the lower dose of donepezil (5 mg)”(10) -Researchers conducting a 2015 pilot study in South Korea found that cognitive enhancement group training programs can positively affect ADLs, cognition, and depression in persons with dementia.(31) Subjects participated in programs such as stacking blocks, playing music, throwing darts, and arts and crafts projects

Exercise –Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  assessed the effectiveness of exercise programs for patients with dementia. The effect of exercise on cognition, ADLs, and depression wasexamined(41) -Included 20 RCTs (N = 2051 patients with dementia) -According to the sensitivity analysis, exercise programs may play an important role in cognition and ADLs in patients with dementia. The most beneficial effects were seen in patients with an average age ˂ 80 years old when compared to usual care. Exercise programs significantly improved ADLs in patients with dementia when compared to usual care -Depression levels did not change with exercise programs

Environmental modifications(3) –Authors of a review of literature that included both pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic interventions for functional and cognitive limitations in patients with mild to moderate dementia found that there was insufficient evidence to draw firm conclusions about environmental modifications(10) –Possible environmental modifications to promote independence or improve safety for patients with dementia include:(8) -Place frequently used items in visible locations -Avoid overstimulation by removing excess clutter or extraneous distractions -Install locked covers to prevent access to dangerous household items such as scissors, knives, and matches -Install locks on windows or doors that pose safety hazards (jumping/falling) or wandering risks -Remove knobs from stove -Install pads on bed rails -Use large pictures, theme pictures, or color-coding as landmarks to define space -Maintain a comfortable temperature in the home to avoid agitation or distress -Keep pathways and stairways clear of obstacles -Ensure lighting throughout the home is adequate -Keep trash bins covered and frequently changed to avoid unpleasant smells that might be agitating or distressing

Group therapy/support group –Group therapy and support groups for patients with dementia and their caregivers can provide social and emotional support and improve overall QOL and well-being(12) –Researchers who conducted an RCT in Hong Kong examined the effect of a family-led  support group for individuals with dementia on the health status of both patients and caregivers(12) -Eighty patient-caregiver  dyads were randomized to a support group or routine-care  group -Support group was made up of eight biweekly, 2-hour group sessions over the course of 6 months -Goals of the support group -Providing information about dementia, including prognosis, current treatment, and care -Developing an extended social support network with relatives and friends -Discussing emotional impacts of caregiving -Learning about both self-care  and motivation -Improving interpersonal relationships of the patient and his or her family members -Establishing a support network of community groups and healthcare resources -Improving problem-solving  skills within the family -At the conclusion of the study, researchers found that the individuals with dementia who participated in the experimental support group had either improvement in symptoms or a slowdown in the worsening of several pathological behaviors (e.g., hallucinations and aggressive behaviors) as well as fewer and/or shorter periods of institutionalization(12)

Animal-assisted  therapy (AAT) –AAT is intended to promote improvement in a person’s physical, social, emotional, or cognitive functioning and can be provided in a variety of settings, including groups or individual sessions. Trained animals who have met specific criteria can be taught to reinforce behaviors in human patients, such as throwing, walking, or verbally responding. The specific goals of AAT are determined by the treating therapist based on a thorough evaluation –Authors of a systematic review of research on AAT for persons with dementia found that overall research is lacking. Because the variables in studies that involve animals are difficult to control, methodological quality of most studies is poor. Systematic review of the studies that exist on AAT indicates that AAT studies are feasible to conduct, AAT appears to be occupationally stimulating, and AAT might help to improve the QOL of persons with dementia who live in an institution(36) –Authors of a systematic review evaluated the use of AAT in a variety of conditions in adults, including dementia.In regards to dementia they found mixed results. However, they did state that the use of AAT in patients with dementia may help decrease agitation(42) -Most studies have been observational,with small sample sizes. Authors concluded that overall there is not sufficient evidence to implement AAT programs for patients with dementia –For detailed information on AAT, see  Clinical Review…Animal-Assisted Therapy: Occupational Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID: T709228

Telerehabilitation –Telerehabilitation as the potential to reduce costs of delivering interventions and increase accessibility. Recent advances in technology allow for videoconferencing using a variet of devices, including tablets. Researchers are beginning to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of telehealth -Authors of a systematic review found the positive effects of cognitive telerehabilitation interventions to be comparable to those receiving similar treatments via face-to-face  interventions in patients with mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer disease, and frontotemporal dementia(43) -Authors of an RCT compared the results of a dyadic intervention using telehealth compared to the same program delivered face-to-face  during home visits in patients with dementia. They found no significant differences between the two methods of delivery. They concluded that dyadic interventions to treat patients with dementia can successfully be delivered via telehealth, thereby increasing accessibility(44) . maintenance or prevention: Preventive measures with the strongest supporting evidence include hypertension control, head injury prevention, and physical, cognitive, and social activity(2)
Prevention of injuries due to poor judgment and safety awareness may be accomplished through environmental modifications and caregiver education

Providing education to the staff in memory care units or long-term  care facilities that service individuals with dementia is likely to promote and maintain occupational engagement of the residents in these facilities(37)

Caregiver burden is high for spouses and children taking care of a loved one with dementia and the caregiver’s QOL and engagement in meaningful activities can suffer. The OT can provide education and support to the caregiver to support maintenance of an occupational balance(38)
patient education: Educating patients and their families/caregivers is an important part of occupational therapy for dementia(27)

The role of the OT also includes education of day care, nursing home, and/or residential care staff so that these providers can support the patient’s well-being  and offer opportunities for the patient to engage in meaningful activities(27) Activities are identified as meaningful if they provoke feelings of enjoyment or pleasure, provide a sense of connection or belonging, or enable the patient to retain feelings of autonomy or personal identity(14)
